title: Risk for Postpartum Hemorrhage Management
description: A comprehensive care plan for preventing and managing postpartum hemorrhage, focusing on risk assessment, early recognition of bleeding, prompt intervention, and prevention of complications in the immediate postpartum period.

assessments.title: Risk Factor Assessment
points: Assess for history of previous postpartum hemorrhage
Evaluate for uterine overdistention (multiple gestation, polyhydramnios, macrosomia)
Assess for prolonged labor (>24 hours)
Evaluate for precipitous labor (<3 hours)
Assess for use of oxytocin during labor
Evaluate for operative delivery (cesarean section, instrumental delivery)
Assess for placental abnormalities (placenta previa, placenta accreta)
Evaluate for pre-existing bleeding disorders or anticoagulant use
Assess for grand multiparity (>5 previous births)
Evaluate for chorioamnionitis or other infection
assessments.description: Comprehensive risk factor assessment helps identify patients at increased risk for postpartum hemorrhage, allowing for preventive interventions and heightened surveillance

assessments.title: Physical Assessment
points: Assess vital signs (blood pressure, pulse, respiratory rate, temperature)
Evaluate uterine tone and fundal height
Assess lochia (amount, color, consistency, presence of clots)
Evaluate perineal, vaginal, or cesarean incision for bleeding
Assess for signs of hypovolemic shock (tachycardia, hypotension, decreased urine output, pallor)
Evaluate for bladder distention that may impair uterine contraction
Assess hemoglobin and hematocrit levels
Evaluate coagulation studies if indicated
Assess pain level and location
assessments.description: Physical assessment helps identify early signs of hemorrhage and provides baseline data for ongoing monitoring and evaluation of interventions

assessments.title: Psychosocial Assessment
points: Assess patient's understanding of postpartum bleeding and warning signs
Evaluate anxiety level related to bleeding risk or actual bleeding
Assess support system availability
Evaluate impact of hemorrhage risk or actual bleeding on maternal-infant bonding
Assess cultural beliefs or practices related to postpartum bleeding
Evaluate coping mechanisms
assessments.description: Psychosocial assessment helps identify educational needs and emotional support requirements for the patient and family during this potentially stressful situation

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Risk for Bleeding related to pregnancy complications and postpartum factors
definingCharacteristics: Not applicable as this is a risk diagnosis

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Deficient Fluid Volume related to active fluid volume loss as evidenced by increased heart rate, decreased blood pressure, and decreased urine output

goals.statement: Patient will not experience postpartum hemorrhage
indicators: Maintains normal vital signs (HR <100, BP within patient's normal range)
Demonstrates firm uterine tone
Exhibits normal lochia flow (saturates <1 pad per hour)
Maintains hemoglobin and hematocrit within normal limits
Verbalizes understanding of warning signs requiring immediate attention

goals.statement: If hemorrhage occurs, patient will demonstrate adequate tissue perfusion and hemodynamic stability
indicators: Returns to hemodynamic stability within 2 hours of intervention
Maintains adequate urine output (>30 mL/hour)
Demonstrates improved or stabilized hemoglobin and hematocrit levels
Reports decreased anxiety related to bleeding
Exhibits normal skin color and temperature

interventions.title: Hemorrhage Prevention
actions: Administer prophylactic uterotonics (oxytocin, methylergonovine, or prostaglandins) as prescribed
Perform frequent fundal checks to ensure firm uterine tone
Teach patient proper fundal massage technique
Ensure empty bladder to promote uterine contraction
Facilitate early breastfeeding to stimulate natural oxytocin release
Minimize perineal trauma during delivery when possible
Monitor vital signs according to protocol (q15min for 1 hour, q30min for 2 hours, then q4h if stable)
Quantify blood loss accurately using calibrated drapes or weighing pads
rationales: Uterotonics promote uterine contraction and prevent atony
Regular fundal checks allow early detection of uterine atony
Patient-performed fundal massage promotes self-care and ongoing assessment
Full bladder can displace uterus and prevent effective contraction
Breastfeeding stimulates natural oxytocin release promoting uterine contraction
Minimizing trauma reduces bleeding from lacerations
Frequent vital sign monitoring allows early detection of hemodynamic changes
Accurate blood loss quantification prevents underestimation of hemorrhage
interventions.frequency: Continuous during first 24 hours postpartum, then as indicated
specialConsiderations: Modify frequency of assessments based on risk factors and clinical status
Consider cultural practices regarding postpartum care and adapt accordingly
Be aware of medication contraindications (e.g., methylergonovine is contraindicated in hypertensive patients)

interventions.title: Hemorrhage Management
actions: Activate postpartum hemorrhage protocol per facility policy
Perform bimanual uterine compression if atony present
Administer additional uterotonics as prescribed (methylergonovine, carboprost, misoprostol)
Establish large-bore IV access if not already present
Administer crystalloid fluid resuscitation as ordered
Prepare for blood product administration if indicated
Assist with identification and repair of lacerations
Prepare for surgical intervention if bleeding persists (D&C, balloon tamponade, uterine artery embolization, hysterectomy)
Implement continuous vital sign monitoring
Insert indwelling urinary catheter to monitor output
Position patient flat with legs elevated if hypotensive
rationales: Protocol activation ensures coordinated team response
Bimanual compression mechanically controls atonic bleeding
Additional uterotonics address uterine atony through different mechanisms
Large-bore IV access allows rapid fluid and blood product administration
Crystalloid fluids restore intravascular volume temporarily
Blood products replace lost components and improve coagulation
Repair of lacerations addresses traumatic sources of bleeding
Surgical interventions may be necessary for persistent hemorrhage
Continuous monitoring tracks response to interventions
Urinary catheter allows accurate measurement of renal perfusion
Positioning improves venous return and cardiac output
specialConsiderations: Consider point-of-care testing for hemoglobin and coagulation if available
Maintain awareness of potential for disseminated intravascular coagulation
Recognize that visual estimation of blood loss typically underestimates actual loss by 30-50%

interventions.title: Patient Education and Support
actions: Explain all procedures and interventions
Teach patient to report increased bleeding immediately
Provide emotional support during hemorrhage management
Include support person in education when appropriate
Explain normal vs. abnormal postpartum bleeding patterns
Teach signs of delayed postpartum hemorrhage to report after discharge
Provide written discharge instructions regarding bleeding concerns
Address concerns about impact on breastfeeding and bonding
rationales: Explanation reduces anxiety and promotes cooperation
Early reporting allows prompt intervention
Emotional support reduces psychological trauma
Including support person extends monitoring after discharge
Understanding normal patterns helps identify abnormal bleeding
Education on delayed hemorrhage promotes safety after discharge
Written instructions serve as reference after discharge
Addressing breastfeeding concerns promotes continued bonding
specialConsiderations: Adapt education to patient's language and health literacy level
Consider cultural beliefs about postpartum bleeding
Recognize potential for posttraumatic stress following severe hemorrhage

evaluations.statement: Has postpartum hemorrhage been prevented or effectively managed?
expectedOutcomes: Maintains normal vital signs (HR <100, BP within patient's normal range)
Demonstrates firm uterine tone
Exhibits normal lochia flow (saturates <1 pad per hour)
Maintains or returns to normal hemoglobin and hematocrit levels
Maintains adequate urine output (>30 mL/hour)
Reports comfort with uterine tone and minimal cramping

evaluations.statement: Does patient demonstrate understanding of postpartum bleeding management?
expectedOutcomes: Verbalizes understanding of warning signs requiring immediate attention
Demonstrates proper fundal massage technique
Accurately describes normal vs. abnormal bleeding patterns
Identifies appropriate actions if increased bleeding occurs
Expresses confidence in self-monitoring after discharge

title: Risk for Impaired Parenting Management
description: A comprehensive care plan for preventing and addressing impaired parenting, focusing on assessment of parenting readiness, promotion of parent-infant attachment, education on newborn care, and support for parents experiencing challenges in the transition to parenthood.

assessments.title: Parenting Readiness Assessment
points: Assess knowledge and experience with infant care
Evaluate expectations of parenthood and newborn behavior
Assess available support systems (partner, family, friends)
Evaluate financial and material resources for infant care
Assess home environment safety and readiness
Evaluate parent's physical and emotional health status
Assess for history of adverse childhood experiences
Evaluate parent's cognitive and developmental status
Assess cultural beliefs and practices related to parenting and infant care
Evaluate parent's response to infant cues and needs
assessments.description: Comprehensive parenting readiness assessment helps identify knowledge deficits, unrealistic expectations, and resource needs to guide appropriate interventions and support

assessments.title: Risk Factor Assessment
points: Assess for history of substance abuse
Evaluate for signs of perinatal mood disorders (depression, anxiety)
Assess for history of domestic violence or abuse
Evaluate for difficult pregnancy or birth experience
Assess for infant factors (prematurity, congenital anomalies, temperament)
Evaluate for social isolation
Assess for young parental age (<20 years)
Evaluate for single parent status
Assess for financial stressors
Evaluate for history of child protective services involvement
assessments.description: Risk factor assessment helps identify parents who may need additional support and intervention to prevent impaired parenting

assessments.title: Parent-Infant Interaction Assessment
points: Assess parent's comfort holding and handling infant
Evaluate eye contact and verbal interaction with infant
Assess responsiveness to infant cues (hunger, discomfort, fatigue)
Evaluate parent's interpretation of infant behavior
Assess parent's emotional response to infant crying
Evaluate feeding interaction (positioning, responsiveness)
Assess parent's ability to soothe infant
Evaluate expressions of affection toward infant
Assess for negative comments about infant
Evaluate parent's interest in infant's appearance and behavior
assessments.description: Interaction assessment helps identify strengths and areas for improvement in parent-infant relationship and bonding

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Risk for Impaired Parenting related to knowledge deficit, lack of support systems, and unrealistic expectations of infant as evidenced by expressed concerns about ability to care for infant
relatedFactors: Knowledge deficit regarding infant development and care
Unrealistic expectations of infant or self
History of being parented in dysfunctional family
definingCharacteristics: Not applicable as this is a risk diagnosis

relatedFactors: Infant with congenital anomaly or illness
definingCharacteristics: Not applicable as this is a risk diagnosis

goals.statement: Parent will demonstrate effective parenting skills and positive interactions with infant
indicators: Demonstrates appropriate holding, feeding, and basic care techniques
Responds appropriately to infant cues and needs
Verbalizes realistic expectations of infant behavior
Demonstrates positive verbal and non-verbal interactions with infant
Expresses positive feelings about parenting role

goals.statement: Parent will identify and utilize appropriate support systems and resources
indicators: Identifies at least two support persons to assist with infant care
Demonstrates knowledge of community resources for parenting support
Verbalizes plan for managing stressful situations
Schedules and attends follow-up appointments
Contacts healthcare provider appropriately with concerns

interventions.title: Attachment Promotion
actions: Facilitate early and frequent skin-to-skin contact
Encourage rooming-in when possible
Teach parent to recognize infant cues and states
Demonstrate and encourage eye contact during feeding and care
Promote breastfeeding if desired by mother
Encourage parent to talk, sing, and read to infant
Model positive interaction with infant
Point out infant's unique characteristics and responses
Create private, calm environment for parent-infant interaction
Involve both parents in infant care when possible
rationales: Skin-to-skin contact promotes oxytocin release and bonding
Rooming-in allows continuous interaction and learning opportunities
Recognition of cues improves responsiveness and confidence
Eye contact promotes attachment and neurological development
Breastfeeding provides close contact and hormonal support for bonding
Verbal interaction promotes language development and connection
Modeling demonstrates positive interaction techniques
Highlighting uniqueness promotes parental investment
Private environment reduces stress and promotes focus on infant
Involving both parents promotes shared parenting responsibility
specialConsiderations: Adapt approaches for NICU situations or maternal illness
Consider cultural beliefs about newborn care and bonding
Be sensitive to parents with history of trauma or loss

interventions.title: Parent Education
actions: Teach basic infant care skills (bathing, diapering, feeding, safety)
Provide information on normal newborn appearance and behavior
Educate about infant states and appropriate responses
Teach soothing techniques for crying infant
Provide anticipatory guidance about developmental milestones
Educate about signs of illness requiring medical attention
Teach safe sleep practices
Provide information on feeding cues and techniques
Educate about postpartum adjustment and self-care
Teach stress management techniques
rationales: Basic care skills build confidence and competence
Understanding normal appearance reduces unnecessary concerns
Knowledge of infant states improves appropriate responsiveness
Soothing techniques reduce parental stress and infant distress
Anticipatory guidance prepares parents for future development
Recognition of illness signs promotes timely intervention
Safe sleep practices reduce SIDS risk
Understanding feeding cues improves nutrition and reduces frustration
Self-care knowledge promotes parental wellbeing
Stress management improves parenting capacity
interventions.frequency: Daily during hospitalization and at discharge
specialConsiderations: Adapt teaching to parent's learning style and health literacy
Provide written materials to reinforce verbal teaching
Consider cultural beliefs and practices in education

interventions.title: Support System Enhancement
actions: Assess existing support network and resources
Provide information about community resources (parenting classes, support groups)
Facilitate connection with peer support programs
Refer to home visitation programs if available
Connect with social services for material needs if indicated
Assist in developing plan for postpartum support at home
Provide information about childcare resources if needed
Screen for and address postpartum mood disorders
Facilitate referrals to mental health services if indicated
Schedule appropriate follow-up appointments
rationales: Assessment identifies gaps in support system
Community resources extend support beyond hospitalization
Peer support normalizes parenting challenges
Home visitation provides ongoing assessment and support
Addressing material needs reduces stress and improves parenting capacity
Postpartum planning prevents isolation and overwhelm
Childcare resources support parents returning to work
Early identification of mood disorders prevents parenting impairment
Mental health services address underlying conditions affecting parenting
Follow-up appointments ensure continuity of care
interventions.frequency: Prior to discharge with follow-up as indicated
specialConsiderations: Consider cultural factors influencing acceptance of support
Recognize barriers to accessing resources (transportation, language)
Maintain non-judgmental approach to avoid stigmatization

Demonstrates positive verbal and non-verbal interactions with infant

title: Risk for Infection Management (Postpartum)
description: A comprehensive care plan for preventing and managing postpartum infections, focusing on risk assessment, early recognition of infection signs, implementation of preventive measures, and prompt treatment of infections in the postpartum period.

assessments.title: Risk Factor Assessment
points: Assess for prolonged rupture of membranes (>18 hours)
Evaluate for prolonged labor
Assess for multiple vaginal examinations during labor
Evaluate for operative delivery (cesarean section, instrumental delivery)
Assess for retained placental fragments
Evaluate for postpartum hemorrhage
Assess for anemia
Evaluate for obesity
Assess for diabetes or gestational diabetes
Evaluate for chorioamnionitis or other antepartum infections
Assess for urinary catheterization
Evaluate for immune compromise
assessments.description: Comprehensive risk factor assessment helps identify patients at increased risk for postpartum infection, allowing for preventive interventions and heightened surveillance

assessments.title: Physical Assessment
points: Assess vital signs (temperature, pulse, respiratory rate, blood pressure)
Evaluate uterine fundus for tenderness, size, and position
Assess lochia for amount, color, odor, and consistency
Evaluate perineal repair site or cesarean incision for redness, swelling, drainage, or dehiscence
Assess breasts for signs of mastitis (redness, tenderness, warmth)
Evaluate for urinary symptoms (frequency, urgency, dysuria)
Assess for respiratory symptoms
Evaluate for calf tenderness or swelling (DVT)
Assess white blood cell count if indicated
Evaluate for general malaise, chills, or other systemic symptoms
assessments.description: Physical assessment helps identify early signs of infection and provides baseline data for ongoing monitoring and evaluation of interventions

assessments.title: Knowledge Assessment
points: Assess patient's understanding of infection prevention measures
Evaluate knowledge of personal hygiene practices
Assess understanding of perineal care or incision care
Evaluate knowledge of signs and symptoms requiring medical attention
Assess understanding of medication administration if prescribed
Evaluate knowledge of hand hygiene importance
Assess understanding of environmental factors affecting infection risk
assessments.description: Knowledge assessment helps identify educational needs to empower the patient in infection prevention and early recognition of infection signs

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Risk for Infection related to invasive procedures, tissue trauma, and altered immune function
relatedFactors: Invasive procedures (cesarean delivery, episiotomy, instrumental delivery)
Inadequate primary defenses (broken skin, traumatized tissue)
definingCharacteristics: Not applicable as this is a risk diagnosis

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Ineffective Protection related to abnormal blood profiles and drug therapies as evidenced by deficient immunity

goals.statement: Patient will remain free from signs and symptoms of infection
indicators: Maintains normal temperature (<38°C)
Demonstrates normal lochia without foul odor
Exhibits well-approximated incision or perineal repair without redness, swelling, or drainage
Reports absence of pain beyond expected discomfort
Maintains white blood cell count within normal limits

goals.statement: Patient will demonstrate knowledge of infection prevention measures
indicators: Demonstrates proper hand hygiene technique
Performs appropriate perineal care or incision care
Verbalizes signs and symptoms requiring medical attention
Demonstrates proper pad changing technique
Describes appropriate antibiotic use if prescribed

interventions.title: Infection Prevention
actions: Implement strict hand hygiene before and after patient contact
Use aseptic technique for all invasive procedures
Administer prophylactic antibiotics for cesarean delivery as prescribed
Teach and reinforce proper perineal hygiene (front-to-back wiping, frequent pad changes)
Instruct on proper incision care for cesarean delivery
Encourage early ambulation to prevent urinary stasis and atelectasis
Promote adequate nutrition and hydration
Ensure proper handling and disposal of contaminated materials
Minimize urinary catheterization duration
Encourage breastfeeding to enhance immune function
rationales: Hand hygiene is the most effective method to prevent infection transmission
Aseptic technique prevents introduction of pathogens during procedures
Prophylactic antibiotics reduce surgical site infection risk
Proper perineal hygiene reduces bacterial colonization and ascending infection
Proper incision care promotes healing and prevents contamination
Early ambulation improves circulation and prevents complications
Adequate nutrition supports immune function
Proper handling prevents cross-contamination
Minimizing catheterization reduces urinary tract infection risk
Breastfeeding enhances maternal and infant immune function
specialConsiderations: Modify approach for patients with specific risk factors
Consider cultural practices regarding postpartum hygiene
Be aware of antibiotic resistance patterns in facility

interventions.title: Infection Surveillance
actions: Monitor vital signs according to protocol (minimum q4h for 24 hours)
Assess uterine fundus for tenderness, size, and position q4h
Evaluate lochia for amount, color, odor, and consistency q4h
Inspect perineal repair site or cesarean incision daily
Assess breasts daily for signs of mastitis
Monitor white blood cell count as indicated
Assess for urinary symptoms with each void
Evaluate for signs of thrombophlebitis (calf pain, swelling, warmth)
Document and report abnormal findings promptly
Collect specimens for culture as indicated
rationales: Regular vital sign monitoring allows early detection of infection
Fundal assessment detects endometritis
Lochia assessment identifies signs of infection
Incision inspection detects early signs of wound infection
Breast assessment identifies early mastitis
WBC monitoring tracks inflammatory response
Urinary symptom assessment detects UTI
Thrombophlebitis assessment identifies venous complications
Prompt reporting facilitates early intervention
Cultures identify specific pathogens to guide treatment
interventions.frequency: According to protocol and patient condition
specialConsiderations: Increase frequency of assessments for high-risk patients
Consider baseline temperature variations in interpreting fever
Be aware that some infections may present subtly in postpartum period

interventions.title: Patient Education
actions: Teach signs and symptoms of infection requiring medical attention
Demonstrate proper hand hygiene technique
Instruct on perineal care or incision care techniques
Teach proper pad changing frequency and technique
Educate about importance of completing full course of antibiotics if prescribed
Instruct on proper nutrition to support healing
Teach signs of mastitis and prevention measures
Provide written discharge instructions regarding infection prevention
Instruct on environmental factors affecting infection risk
Teach proper infant care to prevent cross-contamination
rationales: Knowledge of warning signs promotes early intervention
Hand hygiene reduces pathogen transmission
Proper care techniques prevent contamination
Frequent pad changes reduce bacterial growth
Completing antibiotics prevents resistant infections
Nutrition supports immune function and healing
Early recognition of mastitis allows prompt treatment
Written instructions serve as reference after discharge
Environmental awareness reduces infection risk
Proper infant care prevents cross-contamination
specialConsiderations: Adapt education to patient's language and health literacy level
Consider cultural beliefs about postpartum practices
Recognize barriers to implementing recommendations at home

evaluations.statement: Has patient remained free from signs and symptoms of infection?
expectedOutcomes: Maintains normal temperature (<38°C)
Demonstrates normal lochia without foul odor
Exhibits well-approximated incision or perineal repair without redness, swelling, or drainage
Reports absence of pain beyond expected discomfort
Maintains white blood cell count within normal limits
Demonstrates absence of urinary symptoms

evaluations.statement: Does patient demonstrate knowledge of infection prevention measures?
expectedOutcomes: Demonstrates proper hand hygiene technique
Performs appropriate perineal care or incision care
Verbalizes signs and symptoms requiring medical attention
Demonstrates proper pad changing technique
Describes appropriate antibiotic use if prescribed
Identifies strategies to prevent infection at home
